results.title: Bridging the gap: the many worlds of Mandawuy
results.creator_credit: Kevin Ryder, John Walsh and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
Paolo Totaro hosts a discussion between Rhoda Roberts (Vox Populi), Sonia Voumard (The Age) and Mandawauy Yunupingu (teacher, musican, ambassador and father), on the eve of National Aborigines Day. Mandawuy explores the ways he is bridging the gap between black and white culture through both his band Yothu Yindi, the first aboriginal band to make the charts and to sign with an American record company; and as the Principal of the Yirrkala Community School in North East Arnhem Land, where, as the first aboriginal headmaster, he devised the curriculum mix of aboriginal and western studies known as “Both Ways Education”.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Kevin Ryder, John Walsh and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service

results.title: Mungo lady
results.creator_credit: Mari Bennett, Rachel Perkins and Blackfella Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “From spirit to spirit (A)”.
In 1960 the remains of an Aboriginal woman were exhumed at Lake Mungo, NSW by the white anthropologist/archaeologist, Alan Thorne. The woman had been cremated at least 25,000 years ago, providing the first evidence of this practice, and evidence for elaborate funerary customs by Aborigines in pre-historic times. The remains were exhibited around the world, before being returned to the Aborigines in 1990. This program takes a look at this incident from an Aboriginal perspective.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mari Bennett, Rachel Perkins and Blackfella Films

results.title: Australian aborigines: living off the land
results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and A I F
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Taken during the University of Sydney’s 1952 expedition to Arnhem Land. This film shows how aborigines live on native animals and plants.

results.title: Australian Aborigines: everything from nature
results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Our reliance on manufactured goods is contrasted with the aborigines’ ability to use natural materials around them, which gives rise to a marked respect for their adaptability and sensitivity to the environment. Taked during an expedition by Sydney University to Arnhem Land in 1952.

results.title: From sand to celluloid
results.creator_credit: Bill McCrow, Warwick Thornton, Darlene Johnson, Rima Tamou, Sally Riley, Richard Frankland, Franco Di Chiera, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: An impressive collection of Australian short films by Indigenous filmmakers which explore the history and contradictions of Aboriginal identity. Richard Frankland’s “No Way to Forget” is the story of a young man, working on the Royal Commission on Black Deaths in Custody, who drives home to Melbourne and is haunted by the ghosts of the dead. dead. In Sally Riley’s “Fly Peewee Fly!”, a young boy teaches his white grandmother and his Koorie father a few lessons on perspective. Rima Tamou’s “Round Up” is a tender story about two country boys who discover that their racial differences are not so acute when they are confronted with the multiculturalism and subcultures of the inner-city. In “Two Bob Mermaid” Darlene Johnson presents a beautifully filmed story about a young girl who can pass for white in a racially divided 1957 Australia. Warwick Thornton’s “Payback” presents a surreal story of a young convict who has to obey tribal lore as much as he does white law. Bill McCrow’s “Black Man Down” explores the need for contemporary Aborigines to be aware of the lessons and spirituality of the past.

results.title: Out of darkness
results.brief_description: Robyn Williams narrates this history of the Aborigines in Australia and the archaeological discoveries that have pieced together this history. Until the 1960’s it was thought that the Aborigines had only been here 10,000 years, but discoveries made since then have pushed this timespan as far back as 50,000 years. The predecessors of the modern Aborigines had a sophisticated culture during the ice age, making Aboriginal culture the longest surviving culture in the world.

results.title: The Killing times
results.brief_description: In August 1928, in the desert of Central Australia, seven white Australians murdered seventeen members of the Walbiri tribe. The Coniston Massacre, as it became known, was the last large-scale massacre of Aborigines in Australia. This video dramatises the massacre and the subsequent Federal Inquiry, as well as the eventual victory of the Walbiri for the right to return and live where they were born. The cast includes Ray Barrett, Max Gillies and Martin Vaughan. Narrated by Bob Plasto. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: Mimi pulka
results.creator_credit: Catherine Adams, Ruth Carr, SBS-TV and Voice Productions
results.brief_description: In an effort to break down existing myths about HIV/AIDS and present the information in a way that was culturally appropriate for Aborigines, the Kimberley Aboriginal Medical Service in Broome commissioned a play entitled “No prejudice” and sent it on tour throughout the Kimberley region. This video follows the touring company of five actors and advisers and highlights the importance of why alternatives to the written word are necessary to a people whose culture is essentially oral.

results.title: Still on the same way
results.creator_credit: Graham Cavanagh, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Orcalia Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
With the help of the First Nations people from Gilwi Community (near Timber Creek, Northern Territory), Bob Ellis of the Sacred Sites Authority and spokesmen from the Northern Land Council, this program explores what sacred sites are, some First Nations concepts of land tenure and how development by white Australia is managed in the Northern Territory through a mandatory consultation process, set down in the Aboriginal Land Rights Act.

results.title: The Broken covenant
results.creator_credit: David M. Thompson, ABC-TV (Australia) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Encounters”.
Many of Australia’s urban First Nations people live in appalling physical conditions and are seen by some Australians as outcasts. But to Father Ted Kennedy, a Catholic priest who works in the inner-city suburb of Redfern, many of these marginalised people retain an essential quality of life missing in white society.
